content: The "Business Checking Freedom Act of 2003" authorizes interest-bearing transaction accounts for all businesses. The "Business Checking Freedom Act of 2003" allows depository institutions to permit owners of interest-bearing accounts to make up to 24 transfers per month to another account in the same institution. The "Business Checking Freedom Act of 2003" allows account owners to make up to 24 transfers per month to another account in the same institution, as determined by the Board of Governors of the Federal Reserve System. SEC. 3. Payment of interest on reserves at Federal Reserve Banks. The Federal Reserve Act is amended to allow depository institutions to earn interest on balances maintained at a Federal Reserve bank, with payments made quarterly at rates not exceeding short-term interest rates. The Board may establish regulations regarding these payments and distributions. The Federal Reserve Act allows depository institutions to earn interest on balances at a Federal Reserve bank, with payments made quarterly at rates not exceeding short-term interest rates. The Board may establish regulations for payment and distribution of earnings to these institutions. The responsibilities of depository institutions, Federal home loan banks, and the National Credit Union Administration Central Liquidity Facility regarding the crediting and distribution of earnings from balances maintained at a Federal Reserve bank. The responsibilities include crediting and distributing earnings from balances held at a Federal Reserve bank on behalf of depository institutions, trust companies, and corporations organized under specific sections. The text chunk discusses the definition of an institution, including trust companies, corporations under specific sections, and branches of foreign banks. It also mentions amendments to the Federal Reserve Act regarding member banks and technical changes. The Federal Reserve Act is amended to remove the phrase "which is not a member bank" in Section 19(c)(1)(B). Additionally, technical changes are made in subsections (b)(4) and (c)(1)(A) of the Act. SEC. 4. INCREASED FEDERAL RESERVE BOARD FLEXIBILITY IN SETTING RESERVE REQUIREMENTS. Amends the Federal Reserve Act to allow for a reserve ratio not greater than 3 percent (which may be zero) and not less than 8 percent (which may be zero). SEC. 5. TRANSFER OF FEDERAL RESERVE SURPLUSES. The Federal Reserve Act is amended to allow additional transfers from surplus funds to cover interest payments for fiscal years 2003 through 2007. The Federal Reserve banks will transfer necessary sums from surplus funds to the Board for the Secretary of the Treasury to deposit in the general fund to cover the net cost of section 19(b)(12) for fiscal years 2003 through 2007. The Federal Reserve Board will determine the amount each bank must pay in each fiscal year. The Federal Reserve banks will transfer funds to cover the net cost of section 19(b)(12) for fiscal years 2003 through 2007. Each bank's payment amount will be determined by the Federal Reserve Board. No bank can replenish its surplus fund with the transferred amount during this period. During fiscal years 2003 through 2007, any excess amount in the surplus fund of a Federal Reserve bank will be transferred to the Treasury if it exceeds 3 percent of the paid-in capital and surplus of member banks.
